titleInfo.title: Map of Washington County, Tenn. for use of county health department

mods.abstract: Blueprint map of Washington County (Tenn.) made for use by the county health department. Map shows white and "colored" schools, communities and towns, civil districts, roads, and portions of the Southern Railway and the Carolina, Clinchfield and Ohio Railway. Possibly from the 1930s.

Washington County is Tennessee's oldest county, organizing itself as the Washington District in the early 1770s until it was annexed by North Carolina and officially dubbed Washington County in 1777. It was a part of the failed State of Franklin in the 1780s, and the territory south of the River Ohio in the 1790s, before ultimately joining Tennessee after admittance to the Union in 1796. It is named for General and President George Washington. Its county seat is Jonesborough, named for North Carolina statesman Willie Jones, while its largest city is Johnson City, is named for an early settler, Henry Johnson. Johnson City briefly changed its name to Haynesville during the Civil War to honor Confederate senator Landon Carter Haynes.
